entries.meaning: One who or that which lopes; a runner; a leaper.
(ropemaking) A swivel placed at one end of the ropewalk, with the whirl being at the opposite end.

description: From American Spanish lobo (“wolf”) (/ˈloβo/), reinterpreted as or conflated with loper (“one who lopes”); compare the alternative forms which reflect other re-interpretations and conflations.

entries.meaning: (Southwestern US dialects) A wolf, especially a grey or timber wolf.
examples: When I was still some distance above the ford, about a dozen prairie wolves and one loper* wolf ran up from the water. They told me that there were no Indians  near here or they would not be here; and they were not here long, either. [...] the big loper left on a slow gallop [...]
